description: A magnificent 108-hectare (270-acre) botanical garden located on the Black Sea coast at the Green Cape, 9 km north of Batumi. Founded by Russian botanist Andrey Krasnov in the 1880s and officially opened in 1912, it houses over 2,000 species of plants from around the world organized into nine distinct floristic sectors representing different global regions.
highlights: 108 hectares (270 acres) spanning coastal slopes and cliffs
Over 2,000 species and cultivars of woody plants from across the globe
Founded by renowned Russian botanist Andrey Nikolayevich Krasnov (1862-1914)
Nine floristic sectors: Caucasian humid subtropics, East Asia, New Zealand, South America, Himalayas, Mexico, Australia, and Mediterranean
Extensive collections of rhododendrons, camellias, and magnolias
Groves of bamboo, eucalyptus, and palm trees
Located at Mtsvane Kontskhi (The Green Cape)
One of the largest botanical gardens in the former Soviet Union
Major center for study and conservation of subtropical flora
Stunning panoramic Black Sea views from multiple vantage points
tips: Budget at least 3-4 hours for a full visit to explore properly
Arrive early in the morning to avoid heat and crowds
Wear comfortable walking shoes - paths are steep in parts due to slope location
Consider hiring an electric car (10 GEL one-way) if you have mobility issues
Bring water and snacks, though cafes are available on-site
Spring (April-May) is ideal for flowering rhododendrons and magnolias
Fall offers beautiful autumn colors and pleasant temperatures
Guided tours in multiple languages available for deeper insights
Don't miss the panoramic viewpoints for stunning Black Sea photography
Accessible by minibus from Batumi or scenic hiking trail from Mtsvane Kontskhi railway station
Open 7 days a week from 9am to 5:30pm including public holidays
Entrance fee: 20 GEL for visitors, 10 GEL for Georgian citizens
vibe: Serene, educational, and breathtakingly beautiful. The garden offers a peaceful escape from city life, with the combination of exotic plants, endemic Colchis forest, and dramatic Black Sea coastal views creating an almost otherworldly atmosphere. The distinct botanical zones take visitors on a journey around the world's flora without leaving Georgia.
expectations: A well-maintained botanical garden with labeled plants
Beautiful coastal setting with sea views
Diverse plant collections from different regions
Educational experience learning about subtropical flora
reality: The sheer scale (108 hectares) is overwhelming - much larger than most visitors anticipate
The steep terrain creates a challenging but rewarding hiking experience
The views of the Black Sea from cliff-side locations are absolutely spectacular
The subtropical climate creates a humid, lush atmosphere unlike typical gardens
Each floristic sector feels like entering a completely different country
The historical significance and century-old specimens add profound depth
3-4 hours is barely enough to see everything properly
The garden serves serious scientific purposes beyond just tourism
Weather can change quickly due to coastal location - bring layers
unique_facts: Founded by Andrey Krasnov in the 1880s, officially opened November 3, 1912
Aided by French decorator D'Alphonse and Georgian Yason Gordeziani
Original area was covered in endemic Colchis forest in the 1890s
Krasnov chose the location for its warm, wet, subtropical climate perfect for exotic plants
Land originally purchased by a local botanist to build his country house
Contains 2,037 taxonomic units of woody plants including 104 Caucasian species
Located at Mtsvane Kontskhi meaning 'The Green Cape' in Georgian
Among the largest botanical gardens in the former Soviet Union
Serves as major research center for subtropical flora conservation
The garden predates Soviet era but flourished during that period
Situated on coastal slopes providing natural terracing for plant displays
Home to rare and endangered Caucasian plant species
surprises: The garden feels like multiple gardens in one due to distinct climatic zones
You can walk through Mexican desert plants and then Japanese bamboo groves minutes apart
The endemic Colchis forest sections transport visitors back to prehistoric times
Many visitors discover they need to return another day to see everything
The Black Sea views from certain sections rival any coastal scenic drive
Electric car service available - the garden recognizes its challenging terrain
Accessible by scenic railway line along the Georgian coast
The garden continues active research and conservation over 110 years after founding
Some plant specimens are over 100 years old, planted by Krasnov himself
The International Camellia Society recognizes the garden's exceptional camellia collection
Despite tourist popularity, it maintains its scientific and educational mission
The combination of botanical diversity and coastal location makes it unique globally
